| **Vorausschau – Was wird passieren?** | **Prognostische (inferenzielle) Modelle** | Lineare/Logistische Regression, Random Forest, Zeitreihen‑Forecasts, Konfidenz­intervalle für Prognosen |
| **Vorausschau – Was muss passieren, damit es eintritt?** | **Präskriptive (inferenzielle) Verfahren** | Simulation (Monte‑Carlo), Lineare/Ganzzahl‑Optimierung, Entscheidungsbäume mit Unsicherheits‑Berücksichtigung |

## Lageparameter
- Mean bezeichnet das arithmetische Mittel, häufig als „Durchschnitt" bezeichnet: mean()
- Neben dem arithmetischen Mittel existieren weitere Mittelwerte, zum Beispiel das geometrische Mittel
- Der Median ist weniger anfällig für Ausreißer: median()
- Der Modalwert kann auch mit kategorialen Variablen umgehen
- In R existiert kein Befehl für den Modalwert ☹

## Deskriptive Statistik: Übersicht

| Kategorie | Typische Kennzahlen / Techniken |
|--------------------|----------------------------------------------------|
| **Lagemaße** | Mittelwert - Median - Modus |
| **Streuungsmaße** | Spannweite (Range) - Quartilabstand (IQR) - Varianz & Standardabweichung |
| **Formparameter** | Schiefe (Skewness) - Wölbung (Kurtosis) |

## Standardabweichung und Varianz
- Bedeutung und Berechnung
- Interpretation im Kontext der Normalverteilung
- Praktische Anwendung mit `sd()` und `var()`

## Wie macht man das in R?

| Kennzahl           | R‑Befehl                         | Kurzbeschreibung                          |
|--------------------|----------------------------------|-------------------------------------------|
| Mittelwert         | `mean(data)`                     | Durchschnitt aller Werte                  |
| Median             | `median(data)`                   | Zentralwert (50 %-Quantil)                |
| Minimum            | `min(data)`                      | Kleinster Wert                            |
| Maximum            | `max(data)`                      | Größter Wert                              |
| Spannweite         | `diff(range(data))`              | Abstand = Max − Min                       |
| Standardabweichung | `sd(data)`                       | Ø‑Abweichung vom Mittelwert               |
| Varianz            | `var(data)`                      | Quadrat der Standardabweichung            |
| Schiefe            | `skewness(data)` *(moments/e1071)* | Asymmetrie der Verteilung                 |
| Wölbung (Kurtosis) | `kurtosis(data)` *(moments/e1071)* | "Spitzheit" der Verteilung               |
| Quantile           | `quantile(data, c(.25,.5,.75))`  | 25 %, 50 %, 75 %-Werte (Quartile)         |

# Sitzung 5: Datenvisualisierung

## Warum Datenvisualisierung?

> The greatest value of a picture is when it forces us to notice what we never expected to see.
(John Tukey)

## 5 wichtige Schritte
1. Was ist der Kontext?
   - An wen wird kommuniziert?
   - Was soll der Empfänger wissen oder tun?
   - Welche Daten sind vorhanden, um den Case zu untermauern?
2. Welche ist das passendste Visualierung?
   - Ein oder zwei Zahlen, die im Fokus stehen? => Text!
   - Liniendiagramme für continuous data
   - Säulendiagramme für kategoriale Daten, müssen bei 0 anfangen
   - Die Beziehungen der Daten untereinander bestimmen die Visualisierung, sofern Sie mehr als eine Variable haben
   - Vermeiden Sie Tortendiagramme, Donuts, 3D, zweite Y-Achsen

## 5 wichtige Schritte, Teil II
3. Entfernen Sie „Clutter"
   1. Entfernen Sie alles, das keinen informativen Mehrwert hat (z.B. Farben für die Ästhetik)
   2. Arbeiten Sie mit freiem Raum
4. Fokussieren Sie die Aufmerksamkeit, wo Sie hin soll
   - Größe, Position und, ja, manchmal auch Farbe nutzen um zu signalisieren, was wichtig ist
   - Wohin gehen die Augen?
5. Nutzen Sie Storytelling
   - Niemand will einfach nur Auflistungen von Zahlen und Diagrammen sehen.
   - Schreiben Sie einen Plot. Anfang, eventuell sogar einen Twist, und ein Ende mit Call to Action (in der Wissenschaft reicht eine Diskussion ☺)
   - Bitte arbeiten Sie nicht einfach nur mechanisch alles ab, was Sie können.

## Farben sinnvoll nutzen, wenn überhaupt
- Farben haben einen zusätzlichen Informationswert (z.B. Rot als Warnung, Gefahr, Blut).
- Einsatz von Farben nur, wenn dadurch auch Informationen transportiert werden!
- Vorsicht: Nicht immer werden Diagramme auch farbig ausgegeben (s/w-Druck, e-ink-Reader), so dass Diagramme auch ohne Farben funktionieren müssen.

## How to identify the right diagram?
- Charts are not decoration – they serve a narrative function
- Each chart type answers a specific kind of question
- Choose based on what you want the audience to see or decide
- Five core purposes:
  - Compare values
  - Show change over time
  - Show distribution of data
  - Show relationships between variables
  - Show composition of data
- Good storytelling starts by picking the right question – not the fanciest chart

## Relationship: Scatter Plot
- Visualizes how two continuous variables relate to each other
- Each dot represents a single observation (person, product, day)
- Great for finding patterns, clusters, outliers, and correlations
- X and Y axes must be numeric and continuous
- Can add a third dimension with dot size or color

## Relationship: Correlogram
- Visualizes correlation strength between multiple variables
- Uses color and size to indicate direction and magnitude
- Positive and negative correlations are easily distinguishable
- Great for spotting patterns, clusters, or redundant variables
- Especially useful in exploratory data analysis

## Relationship: Overlap between Datasets w/ Venn Diagram
- Visualizes shared and unique elements between groups
- Overlaps = common ground; non-overlaps = differences
- Great for comparing categories, traits, or stakeholder interests
- Best with 2–3 groups; max. 5 before it gets confusing

## Relationship: Overlap between Datasets w/ UpSet Diagram
- Visualizes intersections between multiple sets
- More scalable than Venn diagrams for complex overlaps
- Bars show size of each intersection
- Dots show which sets are involved
- Ideal for 4+ groups where Venn diagrams become unclear

## Relationship and Flows: Sankey Diagram
- Visualizes flows between categories
- Width of arrows represents volume or value
- Great for showing distribution, conversions, or processes
- Highlights where resources come from and go to
- Ideal for understanding proportions across stages

## Comparison: Horizontal Bar Chart
- Compares values across categories
- Bars run left to right, making labels easier to read
- Ideal for long category names or many items
- Great for ranking or comparing individual values
- Simple, clear, and easy to scan at a glance

## Comparison: Column Chart
- Compares values across categories using vertical bars
- Best used for ranking, performance, or discrete comparisons
- Works well with few categories and clear labeling
- Avoid rotating labels – keep category names short and readable
- Use consistent baseline (zero) for honest comparisons

## Comparison: Horizontal vs. Vertical Bar Charts
| Feature | Horizontal | Vertical |
|---------|------------|----------|
| Best for | Long category labels, many items | Time-based or logical progression |
| Readability | Easier when labels are long | Requires rotation for long labels |
| Use case | Rankings, survey responses | Trends over time, grouped comparisons |
| Scan direction | Left to right | Bottom to top |
| Visual space | Efficient for many categories | Better for fewer, high-impact bars |

Use horizontal when the text matters more.
Use vertical when the order or time is key.

## Comparison: Circular Bar Plot
- Bar chart in a circular layout, grouped by category or type
- Groups are shown through color coding or radial segments
- Useful for showing patterns across categories in a compact, eye-catching way
- Good for visual storytelling – but not for detailed comparison
- Labels can be hard to read – use with care and strong legend

## Comparison: Diverging Bars
- Visualizes deviation in two directions from a central baseline
- Bars extend left and right to show contrast or polarity
- Commonly used for sentiment, change, or normalized values
- Great for showing balance vs. imbalance across categories
- Can be based on z-scores, means, or neutral reference points

## Comparison: Diverging Lollipop Chart
- Like a diverging bar chart, but with dots instead of full bars
- Cleaner visual with less ink-to-data ratio
- Shows the same polarity or comparison with more elegance
- Great for when precise values matter less than direction and magnitude
- Particularly good in reports and presentations

## Distribution: The Histogram
- Shows the distribution of numerical data over intervals (bins)
- Each bar represents the frequency of values in a given range
- Great for detecting skew, spread, and outliers
- Helps identify modes or clustering in data
- Unlike bar charts, the bars are touching – to reflect continuity

## Distribution: Boxplots – For Experts
- Summarizes data with minimum, quartiles, and median
- Highlights spread, skewness, and outliers
- Excellent for comparing distributions across categories
- Very compact – shows a lot with little space
- Can be hard to interpret for non-technical audiences

## Distribution: Boxplots, in combination with a Violin Plot
- Combines boxplot and density curve in one chart
- Shows distribution shape, spread, and central tendency
- Ideal for comparing multiple groups or conditions
- Reveals skew, multimodality, and outliers more clearly than a boxplot alone

## Distribution: Choropleth Map
- Colors geographic areas based on data values
- Great for showing regional differences or spatial patterns
- Easy to interpret at a glance, especially for ratios or percentages
- Works best with normalized data (e.g. per capita, % change)
- Can be misleading if areas differ greatly in size or population

## Composition: Stacked Area Chart
- Shows how multiple categories contribute to a total over time
- Layers are stacked, making cumulative trends visible
- Good for tracking overall growth and category proportions
- Works best with few categories to avoid clutter
- Hard to compare individual segments precisely

## Composition: Stacked 100% Area Chart
- When you want to show relative proportions, not absolute values
- Ideal for tracking how category shares change over time
- Total always equals 100%, making comparisons easier across time
- Best for emphasizing composition, not growth
- Avoid when total size is also important – absolute trends get lost

## Composition: Waterfall Diagram
- Shows how individual values contribute to a total
- Combines increases and decreases across categories
- Highlights step-by-step change from a starting to an ending value
- Great for explaining variance, profit breakdowns, or budget changes
- Makes it easy to see which factors drive the final result

## Composition: Heatmap
- Uses color intensity to represent values in a matrix
- Great for spotting patterns, clusters, and anomalies
- Works well for correlations, time series, or categorical combinations
- Easy to scan – but not ideal for precise values
- Color scale choice is crucial for correct interpretation

## Composition: Square Area Chart
- Represents parts of a whole using a grid of equal-sized squares
- Each square typically = 1% (in a 10×10 grid)
- Great for showing simple proportions or progress toward a goal
- Easy to read and visually engaging
- Best used with a few categories – not ideal for detailed comparisons

## Composition: Treemap
- Visualizes part-to-whole relationships using nested rectangles
- Size of each square represents a value (e.g. revenue, count)
- Can show hierarchies or groupings visually
- Good for comparing proportions across categories
- Can become hard to read with too many small tiles
